overview: From 2025-12-01 to 2026-01-01, ethereum-optimism/infra had 13 new PRs (9 merged), 0 new issues, and 60 active contributors.

topIssues.title: [acceptance] rollup-boost reversion
topIssues.author: scharissis
topIssues.body: rollup-boost successfully reverts to default EL block building when rbuilder fails, a reorg is detected or block building latency exceeds threshold

topPRs.title: feat(op-acceptor): add multigate and dry-run
topPRs.author: serpixel
topPRs.body:
<!-- Contributions welcome! See https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/.github/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md -->

**Description**

Adds the following convenience functionalities into op-acceptor:

- Multi-gate input (pass multiple gates such as `--gate cgt,flashblocks,jovian`). Deduplicates tests ensuring they're only ran once.
- Dry run mode to see which tests are about to be run.

topPRs.title: fix(op-acceptor): Stream stdout to disk and refactor raw JSON logging
topPRs.author: scharissis
topPRs.body:
Streams the logs straight to disk so we don't use up lots of RAM.
Also implements a signal handler, so we can _try_ to exit gracefully if, say, CircleCI kills our host.

topPRs.title: ci: split worklow runs between protected/unprotected
topPRs.author: falcorocks
topPRs.body:
This pull request refactors the CI workflow configuration for building Docker images in this repository. It consolidates multiple service-specific workflow files into two new workflows: one for protected branches/tags and one for unprotected branches (PRs), streamlining and centralizing the build process. The new approach uses matrix builds and improved tag parsing, making maintenance and scaling easier.

Workflow consolidation and simplification:

* Removed individual workflow files for each service (`cci-stats`, `op-acceptor`, `op-conductor-mon`, `op-conductor-ops`, `op-signer`, `op-txproxy`, `op-ufm`, `peer-mgmt-service`, `proxyd`, `replica-healthcheck`) and replaced them with a single matrix-based build step in the new workflows. [[1]](diffhunk://#diff-df358288c9e27c3cfb8cf2b36c2e71dfc23302153d4ac8c6c261a7045eb22fc6L1-L22) [[2]](diffhunk://#diff-4a8f90ed7b3cc121faaf65c6bb90338e60a923bbeaa53fbbeff5a77d379af820L1-L22) [[3]](diffhunk://#diff-491ef0383c46ca51495347f53f3c8d5528b770d861d46d5b97f46fe762e9470cL1-L22) [[4]](diffhunk://#diff-cf63334561495e94d1fc7800b67d4f061e1cac71937c7a45d4b0dee6a8e4b628L1-L22) [[5]](diffhunk://#diff-4b2cacbffeb4d87db726a7c90b87dfa5024b15304043c080985649051eec003eL1-L22) [[6]](diffhunk://#diff-f5d9a862301b9e54c9e1750aeeb62d24cc536c3263b5fe612c37c71f0eee6ddaL1-L22) [[7]](diffhunk://#diff-188e604b172203ec6aa65dae1130060b682b0c49327a31f8d333c36aebf75e70L1-L22) [[8]](diffhunk://#diff-f95433f3ca2d2867b6b34718397d97cbd2c15ef966fc21861d6ea1d3f8d06632L1-L22) [[9]](diffhunk://#diff-4b9b6557978a1b72379ae3880b8dccdd37a54652d0a28761215fe5a988a92344L1-L22) [[10]](diffhunk://#diff-750e4a4124cca116eaa3b7550a32a01222cac52ff6084171fa687fc3201e2ff9L1-L22)

New protected branch/tag workflow:

* Added `.github/workflows/protected.yml` to build images for tags and the main branch, with logic to parse tags and build the correct image/version, using a matrix for all relevant services.

New unprotected PR workflow:

* Added `.github/workflows/unprotected.yaml` to build images for all services on pull requests to `main`, using a matrix build and temporary image registry.

Improvements to build management:

* Updated Docker build workflow references to use a newer commit of the shared build workflow and standardized registry configuration. [[1]](diffhunk://#diff-6db0d637fbe130c50b893ea95b4427ad68fe6ca056b42b8af79a8546dc4a7d56R1-R73) [[2]](diffhunk://#diff-8fcc26843f40a9be94b8bc400a55c491b2c0e11ea655f2ec63eb445a3aefb42cR1-R34)

topPRs.title: fix(op-acceptor): subtest logging memory leak
topPRs.author: scharissis
topPRs.body:
This fixes a memory leak by capping subtest logs to a small tail.

Sometimes very long running tests (eg. proofs) cause our CCI host to be [killed due to OOM](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/ethereum-optimism/optimism/109947/workflows/1143e819-9bf6-4677-9d64-aed6fdd1bb03/jobs/4178754/resources). Upon investigation I found that while we had capped our top-level test logs we missed the subtest logs. This should fix that.

topPRs.title: fix(op-acceptor): tests; TestCLIServiceFlag
topPRs.author: scharissis
topPRs.body:
Made the CLI skip telemetry/service setup when only --help or --version is requested. Extracted buildApp with tighter exit handling, so help now renders cleanly without triggering required flag validation—fixing the flaky TestCLISerialFlag/help-includes-serial failure.

Resolves https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/platforms-team/issues/1549

completedItems.title: fix(ci): use repo root context in tags workflow
completedItems.body:
The tags workflow was setting context to the image subdirectory while the Dockerfile expects to run from the repo root (matching branches.yaml).

This caused builds to fail with 'not found' errors when Dockerfiles referenced paths like `COP

completedItems.title: fix(ci): goreleaser; make latest release.
completedItems.body: We had 'latest_release' disabled by default for most services. This changes that, so the github repo shows the actual latest release. The currently listed latest release is op-ufm/v0.2.6 from July 25, which is clearly not correct.

topContributors.summary: smartcontracts: Drove significant progress on the OPCMv2 system within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository, landing several major features and refactors. Their most impactful work included breaking out OPCMv2 utilities into helper contracts (#18454) and implementing a new contract check runner (#18553), both of which involved over 2,000 lines of new code. They also improved the upgrade process by making allowances upgrade-specific (#18462) and added extensive tests for the new deployment logic (#18486). This activity shows a primary focus on feature work and bug fixes, with code changes concentrated in test and configuration files.

sbvegan: Drove a significant overhaul of the `ethereum-optimism/docs` repository, focusing on large-scale refactoring and content migration. Key contributions include a major refactor in PR #1909 (+636/-2801 lines), porting the `op-deployer` documentation in PR #1911 (+1526/-891 lines), and fixing extensive formatting issues in PR #1901 (+1529/-1524 lines). In addition to merging 10 pull requests, they actively supported the team by providing 14 code reviews. This month's activity shows a primary focus on improving documentation quality and structure, with contributions also touching on bug fixes.

Inphi: Focused on enhancing the testing and proofing capabilities of the Optimism stack this month, merging several PRs to improve test coverage and CI, including adding tests for delegatecalled precompiles in `ethereum-optimism/optimism#18475`. They demonstrated significant forward-planning by creating 16 issues to scope out future work on proof systems, dispute games, and superchain components. Inphi's 33 code reviews further highlight their collaborative impact, with their contributions primarily focused on tests, configuration, and feature work.

ajsutton: This month, ajsutton drove the implementation of ZK fault proof support within the `op-challenger` service in the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository. After creating initial planning issues (#18322, #18321), they delivered the core functionality through a series of significant pull requests, including the logic to challenge invalid ZK games (#18442), resolve optimistic games (#18464), and reclaim bonds (#18465). In addition to this primary feature work, they provided 13 code reviews to support the team. Their contributions were well-balanced between new code and associated tests, as seen in the file modification statistics.

maurelian: Focused heavily on ensuring code quality through extensive peer review, providing 68 detailed reviews across projects. In parallel, they drove significant new feature development, authoring over 5,500 lines of code for ongoing work like the proposed `SuperFaultDisputeGameV2` (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18565). They also merged a pull request to enforce compiler warnings and improve build stability in the contracts package (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18567). This activity reflects a primary focus on new feature work, bug fixes, and tests.

serpixel: Focused on enhancing deployment tooling and infrastructure, merging eight pull requests this month. They delivered significant new functionality to the `op-acceptor` by adding multigate and dry-run capabilities in `infra#520` (+577/-81 lines). Serpixel also drove the `op-deployer`'s compatibility with the `op-contracts/v5.0.0` upgrade through a series of PRs, including `optimism#18580`. Their work was rounded out by providing 21 code reviews and making several improvements to the CI pipeline for publishing artifacts.

geoknee: Focused on improving the robustness and correctness of the Optimism node and its related components this month. They landed several targeted improvements, most notably adding test coverage for future system configurations in `op-node` (optimism#18566), while also clarifying documentation (docs#1902). Geoknee's largest impact was through collaboration, providing 42 code reviews, and they have initiated significant ongoing work to refactor `op-node` sequencing and recovery logic (optimism#18589, optimism#18556). Their contributions were primarily a mix of bug fixes and enhancing test coverage.

falcorocks: This month, falcorocks focused on enhancing the security and efficiency of the CI/CD infrastructure across multiple repositories. They led a significant effort in `optimism#18501` to reduce permissions for fork builds and fix tag releases, and also refactored workflows to split runs between protected and unprotected branches in `infra#519` and `optimism#18443`. Through 8 merged PRs and 7 code reviews, their work centered on improving build processes and reliability, as reflected in their code changes which were predominantly bugfixes and modifications to configuration files.
almanax-ai: Focused on reviewing pull requests this month, providing feedback through 64 review comments.

janjakubnanista: Focused on improving deployment pipeline stability within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository, merging nine pull requests primarily centered on bug fixes. Their most significant contributions involved backporting extensive pipeline fixes to multiple versions of the `op-deployer` tool (#18538, #18539), ensuring consistency and reliability across releases. They also improved error handling in the deployer's CLI (#18532), created on-call issues to address operational needs (#17859, #18558), and provided 9 code reviews. This work shows a clear focus on the health of deployment tooling, with changes spanning configuration, application code, and tests.

scharissis: Focused on improving the reliability and efficiency of the acceptance testing infrastructure this month. They landed several key fixes for `op-acceptor`, including a significant refactor to stream stdout to disk (`infra#525`) and a fix for a subtest logging memory leak (`infra#526`). Additionally, scharissis improved CI performance by implementing caching and retries for `mise` in `optimism#18572`. Their contributions show a primary focus on bug fixes and test enhancements across code, configuration, and test files.

teddyknox: Focused on integrating new services and testing infrastructure into the Optimism monorepo this month. They merged two substantial pull requests, adding kona-healthcheck support to the conductor (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18453) and incorporating new submodules for acceptance testing (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18540). Alongside this work, they were an active collaborator, providing 20 code reviews and starting a large-scale refactor (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18504). Their code changes primarily involved new functionality and the corresponding test files.

pcw109550: Focused on advancing the `op-node` light client, merging a significant PR in `ethereum-optimism/optimism` (#18571) to ensure the client always follows the source using the consensus layer. This complex feature involved substantial changes (+1494/-1103 lines) and was supported by their creation of a related issue (#18316) and two other open PRs on the same topic. In addition to this core implementation, they were an active collaborator, providing 20 code reviews across the project. Their contributions were primarily focused on new feature work, with a notable portion dedicated to tests and bugfixes.

pauldowman: This month, pauldowman focused on network upgrades and configuration, merging several PRs to add prestates for new releases to the superchain registry (e.g., #1174, #1184). They also improved testing in `op-geth` by adding coverage for a new precompile input size limit in PR #731. A significant portion of their impact came from planning and defining work, creating 12 issues that scoped out tasks for upcoming releases and broke down improvements for the challenger system. Their code contributions primarily involved tests and other supporting changes for these initiatives.

JosepBove: This month, JosepBove focused on significant CI enhancements and chain configurations for the Optimism and Superchain repositories. Their most impactful contribution was adding the Openchain import to CI in `optimism#18447`, a massive undertaking that modified over 100k lines of code. They also deployed a new "safersafes" script in `optimism#18448`, fixed CI issues in `optimism#18450`, and supported the team with 10 code reviews. This work reflects a primary focus on feature implementation and bug fixes, concentrated within documentation and configuration files.

Their most impactful contribution was the introduction of L2 fee splitter contracts in `ethereum-optimism/optimism#18474` (+9815/-833 lines), alongside updating key deployment parameters in `ethereum-optimism/optimism#18490`. In addition to shipping code, they were active in collaboration, providing 9 code reviews and identifying a deployment configuration need in issue `ethereum-optimism/optimism#17505`. Their work was a blend of bug fixes and feature development, with a strong emphasis on testing.

In addition to their own work, which includes three other open PRs, Wazabie supported the team by providing 6 reviews on other pull requests. bearpebble: Focused on bug fixing within the `op-batcher` this month, opening a pull request to fix a loop issue (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18485). This significant effort involved 6 commits and changes across 12 files (+246/-22 lines), with a third of the changes dedicated to tests. They also actively supported their work with 6 PR comments and one review comment.

nktaushanov: Focused on a significant bug fix within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository, opening a pull request to address unordered posting to the alt-da server in concurrent scenarios (#18478). This single, in-progress change is substantial, modifying 293 files with over 10,000 lines of new code. The work shows a clear focus on core functionality and robustness, as a third of the changes were dedicated to tests.

tuxcanfly: Focused on enhancing the `op-batcher`'s alternative data availability (altda) functionality in the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository. They opened a pull request (#18552) to allow for configurable multiple frames per transaction, which included changes across 6 files. In support of this effort, they also created two issues (#18508, #18507) to outline further improvements in this area.
